transcript.text: [Music]
the purpose of this meeting as was
stated before is uh largely
informational for information sharing on
different issues in the Middle East it's
not intended as a forum uh for partisan
presentations of any kind and we hope
that in the question and answer period
everyone will get a chance to ask
questions and that people will limit
their questions so as to allow everyone
to have a chance to uh
participate the format of the meeting is
that we have two speakers
uh first uh Professor Chomsky and then
Professor dtz each speaker will speak
for 20 minutes and then following that
and we ask you to refrain from asking
questions during their speeches or
between the two speeches because
immediately after the two speeches we'll
have about an hour to uh ask
questions both um professor chsky and
Professor dtz will address themselves to
the question of what would would you
consider to be a just and Lasting
solution in the Middle East and first
Professor Chomsky professor of
linguistics at MIT will
speak uh there are quite a lot of things
I'd like to say and I want to try to
keep within the 20 minute limit more or
less I hope more so I hope you'll excuse
me if I uh read most of this instead of
the usual uh rambling which is I suppose
more interesting but uh more likely to
wander off and not get to the points I
want to get to well the topic that we've
been asked to to limit ourselves to
primarily essentially is is the is is in
fact a limited but a very important one
uh and uh I do want to address myself to
it in a moment but it would be pointless
I think to uh try to consider the
question of what would be a just
solution uh to the Arab Jewish conflict
without if if we take this in in total
abstraction from developments in the
region and in the international uh Arena
so what I would like to do then is to
divide my remarks into three parts first
I want to say a couple of things about
the situation as it appears as it
appeared to me to be uh say as of
October 1st 1973 just before the war
second I want to say a couple of things
about the situation as it seems to me to
appear to be Evol U evolving today in
the light of the uh fighting in October
and in this context then finally I want
to talk about principles of what seemed
to me to be a just solution to the
problem and uh also about the prospects
for uh moving to it now only under the
third category will I express directly
at least my own views as to the rights
and the wrongs of this conflict uh but
to avoid any misunderstanding I I ought
to perhaps point out at the beginning
that my own personal views diverge in
what seemed to me at least to be quite
fundamental ways from the positions of
any major party concerned at least as I
understand their
views so you shouldn't be under the Mis
misunderstanding or the belief false
belief that I'm speaking for some
organized group at least that exists so
far as I
know uh the first point then what of the
situation as of immediately prior to the
war say beginning of October well at
that point Israel seemed firmly in
control Israeli generals were assuring
their uh countrymen that Israel was
stronger militarily than any European
NATO power and that it could conquer
most of the Middle East and North Africa
within a week furthermore uh it was
argued that the United States would
continue to support Israel as the
guardian of Western interests uh as
general Rabin put it last July Israel
need not be concerned about military AR
support from the United States because
American experts are saying more and
more openly that if some medieval type
rulers really mean to endanger the oil
needs of hundreds of millions of people
in the Civilized world then the West is
permitted to take harsh steps to prevent
it to prevent this now this view uh this
is the former Ambassador uh who I think
is in fact here or was here recently uh
the this uh view that Israel would be
the Watchdog for Western interests uh to
use a
phrase uh that was I think used first
perhaps first by the editor of haritz in
1951 uh this uh position is not a new
one uh you can trace it far back you can
trace it at least as far as
jabotinsky argument right-wing Zionist
argument during World War I uh when he
argued as follows I'm quoting in the
Middle East nationalism will spread
among indigenous populations only the
stable support of a nation that is
foreign in culture and social forms uh
from other peoples in the region can
serve as a prop for the British forces
in this region thus the zionists tell
the British that support for their
aspirations would assure would assure
the Empire of an important strategic
Outpost under conditions that would
improve as Zionism was
implemented this is at the time of the
uh discussions about the Baler
declaration
now at one time views such as these
views such as javinsky were the views of
reactionary extremists now on the other
hand they're expressed by Leading
political and Military
figures this uh point this change has
been noted by many people in particular
by the very well-informed Zionist
historian John kimchi who uh just
published a useful book on this subject
in which he explains uh that I'm quoting
the decisive development of the past 50
years is that Israel had become the
major military factor in the Middle East
it can strike at will with only the
tacit approval of the US government and
has thus become indispensable to the
United States since the United States
because of the parody uh arrangements
with the Soviet Union is incapable of
striking directly by itself in support
of its
interests now under these assumptions
dual assumptions first as to the
military hegemony of Israel in the
region second uh the general assumption
that it was acting as the Watchdog of
American interests in the area under
these dual assumptions the Israeli
government was proceeding with its plans
for incorporating uh all of the
territories that were occupied in the
1967 war or at least the majority of
those territories in August
1973 a plan quite extensive plans were
announced in the Israeli press for new
settlements in the occupied areas
including New Towns new Villages and so
on for considerable expropriation of
Arab lands for purchase of lands in the
occupied areas by the Jewish National
Fund and recall that the consequence of
that is that Arabs are excluded by law
from uh using or even working on these
lands after that point uh all of this
was in accordance with the position that
was expressed in August by the minister
of Commerce and Industry that I'm
quoting we regard Israel and the
occupied territories as a single
economic unit uh in August the mayor of
Jerusalem Teddy kollock called for
almost doubling the jurisdictional area
of the city and equally significant the
labor alignment that's the ruling party
uh adopted an electoral program that
called for virtual annexation of the
occupied territories this is the Galilee
protocols which were adopted as an
electoral program for the October 31st
elections actually I think if you look
at it carefully that program is worse
than
annexation uh instead of giving my view
let me give the editorial comment in
haritz which is sort of the Israeli New
York Times uh on September 4th which
noted that the government gave its
approval to Dion's demand to set up
settlements and towns within Judea and
Samaria that means the occupied West
Bank without annexation and without
changing its status as an occupied area
through the initiative of Dion will be
possible to take over territories
without annexing them and without
granting their inhabitants the Arabs the
rights of citizens in Israel these plans
incidentally went well beyond the West
Bank for example they included plans for
industrial uh town on the Golan Heights
uh they included plans for developments
in the Rafa area south of Gaza from
which thousands of bedin had recently
been expelled in a recent Scandal that
caused some protest in Israel and they
also included consideration of a deep
water Port south of Gaza and the good
deal else now recall that this is the
electoral program of the governing party
and furthermore the program of the less
expansionist of the two major
parties now I suspect that these
programs were a factor maybe a
significant factor at least in the
timing of the October war and
furthermore they go a long way towards
explaining the hostility towards Israel
on the part for example on the part of
the African States now in the United
States uh it is often this uh hostility
is often described as cowardice in the
face of Arab oil pressure but I'm happy
to say that the Israeli press as usual
is more realistic than it's American
analog uh for uh uh for again in harit a
commentator speaking of the decision of
zir former Congo to break relations with
Israel points out correctly I'm sure
that there is every reason to accept
muto's statement that our continued
settlement of the territories conquered
in
1967 is the main reason for his decision
uh changing borders by Force of Arms is
for reasons peculiar to Africa received
very negatively by African
leaders uh my only qualification is that
there's nothing peculiar to Africa about
that kind of thinking uh in fact the
same kind of reasoning goes a long way
to explain why the European common
market uh has taken the position it has
uh we read here comments by
distinguished professors and others
saying that if United the Western Powers
could resist the oil
boycott and I suppose that's true though
curiously irrelevant because the point
is that these comments fail to recognize
that Western Europe has never accepted
the American policy of support for
permanent Israeli occupation of the
territories and therefore we'll see no
reason to be United in pursuit of this
OB objective with the United States
quite apart from any pressure or
boycott uh Israeli policy has been based
over the last few years with increasing
Clarity uh to the outside and very
likely even to the people themselves who
are implementing it has been based on
the principle that was expressed last
spring by
Dion that quote Jews and Arabs can live
together only under Israeli military
occupation this very
dangerous in my view suicidal policy is
a major factor in the almost complete
diplomatic isolation of Israel uh very
dangerous development for it which
Israel can now really count for support
quite literally only on the United
States South Africa and Portugal and I
suspect not even on these Powers any
longer I've long felt that this was a
suicidal policy and I think that in the
long run and I think that recent events
show that the long run is not so long as
it seemed in any event as of October 1st
these policies did seem fairly
successful and correspondingly American
support for these policies also seemed a
qualified success Israel and Iran were
firmly in the American orbit as were
Jordan and Saudi Arabia which of course
is the centerpiece of this whole story
Egypt had expelled Russian advisor and
was appealing for American Investment
and support the Palestinians had been
crushed in 19 70 and 71 the major oil
producers and the major military Powers
were firmly within the American system
and the forces of radical nationalism
seemed to have been repressed or
constrained there was every reason then
to believe as I'm sure was believed that
the American policy was essentially
succeeding but there was always an
element of risk in this policy plainly
Egypt and Syria would not accept
permanent Israeli occupation though
Jordan and Saudi Arabia might hence
there was was the risk of War but this
risk was universally regarded as slight
on the assumption that Israel remained
the overwhelmingly dominant military
force now Sadat gamble on October 6th
proved to the great surprise of
virtually all observers that this
assumption was fallacious Israel failed
to win a decisive and overwhelming
military Victory it did not succeed in
trampling Arab faces in the mud as its
Arab language broadcasts promised nor
did it succeed in breaking the bones of
the enemy nor did it succeed in
conquering the area from Baghdad to
carum to Algeria within a week as
general Shon had explained it could only
a few months before in fact I think that
the Egyptian Syrian military success
undermined the fundamental Assumption of
us and Israeli policy Saudi Arabia was
compelled to employ the oil weapon my
guess is it was compelled reluctantly
and a very dangerous Rift was created
between the United States and its allies
again I believe that these facts will
set the stage for a significant revision
of US policy and with that let me turn
to the second topic namely the
developing
situation fact is that the United States
has always had a second policy option
and alternative to the policy that has
been pursuing namely what is called the
Rogers plan and I think the United
States will now shift to that policy
this plan requires that Israel return to
something very much like the 196 7
borders in accordance with the UN
resolution as it's understood throughout
most of the
world uh with the militarized zones in
the surrounding areas that's the UN
resolution of November 1967 with the
militarized zones in surrounding areas
with a formal peace treaty including
recognition of Israeli sovereignty and
very likely with some kind of
Palestinian State maybe on the West Bank
and the Gaza Strip a kind of a miniate
which will be subject to the will of
Israel and Jordan which in the past have
followed quite similar policies in this
and other respects and will probably
continue to do so under this plan uh
Saudi Arabia and the gulf oil producers
will return to their role as American
client states and Egypt will join this
system too in accordance with the will
of with the desires of the Egyptian
bourjois and Military the result I think
will be a kind of Latin American
solution with direct American support
for the reactionary Arab states as in
the past now Egypt is well and with
Israel embedded in this system as a kind
of a Garrison State wholly dependent on
the United States still a powerful
military force and the most advanced
industrial society in the region but
with limited aspirations and capacities
more limited at least such an outcome I
think could be stable it would serve the
interests of the superpowers it would
amount to a kind of recolonization of
the Middle East but it has long been
clear that this will be the likely
consequence of the policies pursued by
all of the local actors in This unhappy
confrontation now I'm speculating now of
course but it seems to me that this is
the turn that US policy will take or has
already taken though a bitter political
struggle will probably take place in the
United States and maybe in Israel as the
outlines of this policy become more
clear as for Egypt it accepted the
rogers's plan at once and its public
statements and behavior at least seem to
go along with it as far as I can tell
the same I think is true of Jordan and
Saudi Arabia though the problem of
Jerusalem will likely prove crucial here
the Palestinian leadership which is in
any event powerless has reluctantly
accepted this program apparently under
strong Russian pressure The crucial
question I think is whether Israel will
exceed to us pressure and will renounce
and reverse the policies of the last few
years this will be a bitter pill but I
think that Israel has successively cut
off of its options and now has very
little room to maneuver
if the United States commands I think it
must obey however
reluctantly the most difficult policy
shift in this whole complex in Israel
will be the recognition of the
Palestinians much has been made in the
west of the refusal of the Arab states
to negotiate directly with Israel
irrational in my opinion but it has less
often been noted that Israel not only
refuses categorically to negotiate with
the Palestinians but even officially
denies that they exist the problem is a
very long-standing one it has deep roots
in one aspect they were expressed by the
leader of the extreme right manim Bean
when he warned a kibuts audience of the
danger that was inherent in recognizing
a Palestinian people only a few years
ago
1969 asked about this he responded as
follows my friend take care when you
recognize the concept of Palestine you
demolish your right to live in ANH
if this is Palestine and not the land of
Israel then you are conquerors and not
tillers of the land you are Invaders if
this is Palestine then it belongs to a
people who live here before who lived
here before you came only if it is the
land of Israel do you have a right to
live in Ines and in the B if it is not
your country your Fatherland the country
of your ancestors and of your sons then
what are you doing here you came to
another people's Homeland as they claim
you expelled them and you have taken
their land
now this is the voice of the extreme
right but it touches a chord there's no
doubt of that it echoes an important
debate which I believe will reawaken
again that goes back to the origins of
the Zionist movement for example in 197
Yak Epstein who was an early settler of
the 1880s wrote in a Zionist periodical
that Zionism should be based on Justice
and law absolute equality and human
Brotherhood he called for a radical
change in 19 197 in the approach to the
Arabs saying unless we want to deceive
ourselves deliberately we have to admit
that we have thrown people out of their
miserable lodgings and taken away their
sustenance and he objected to this
policy he was reprimanded as a person
who has what was called a diaspora way
of
thinking uh with the comment that the
main thing we should take into account
is what is good and effective for
ourselves now I can't take the time here
to recount the long debate both before
and after perhaps it's enough to quote
again John kimchi's summary of the long
history of what he calls the Curious
Israeli refusal to consider the
Palestinian solution he says it was as
if the assertion of a Jewish Nation
required the rejection of the existence
of a Palestinian Nation this curious
refusal will have to be overcome if
Israel is to accept the solution that I
suspect will now be imposed by the
superpowers well finally third topic
will this be a just and desirable
solution as I guess is implicit in what
I've been saying I don't think so Israel
will remain a Jewish state that is a
state based and one must admit this I'm
sure a state based on discrimination and
oppression in law and in practice for
there is no other way for a state with
non-jewish citizens to remain a Jewish
state that is to say that there will be
a continuation of the policies which can
be unfortunately well documented of
expropriation of expulsion of the
formation of pure Jewish cities and
residential areas by law and practice of
exclusion of Arabs from State lands
lands owned in the name of the Jewish
people of repression of independent
political activity all of which can well
be documented and it will continue to be
true as the Israeli liberal unnown
Rubenstein who you occasionally read in
the New York Times magazine pointed out
in haritz just a couple of week weeks
ago that the moment the magic word
security is uttered the wheels of the
machine of Justice slow down this
happens even when these security reasons
cannot convince a reasonable man no
experienced lawyer would advise the
uprooted people of theam creit to resort
to court to the court of appeals in
order to fight the closing orders of the
Northern Regional commander who had
illegally evicted them from their lands
experience proves that there is no point
in such appeals this is the view of a
liberal law professor and it is quite
accurate furthermore Israel I believe
under these circumstances will remain a
Garrison State dependent on the
superpowers and it will furthermore
remain a state with a very strong
element of religious coercion internally
it's important to remember that in
Israel today the ravinet is rapidly
developing into a firmly
institutionalized Church imposing an
exacting discipline on its members and
facing the general body of layman as a
distinct power this is not a religious
development but it ironically enough it
is the outcome of the emergence of the
state the latter has given birth and
legitimacy to an established church and
that's not my view solely I was quoting
all of those remarks from Jacob Talman
the outstanding and rather conservative
uh uh historian of the Hebrew University
who points out incidentally that none of
these developments have any root Roots
at all in Jewish tradition though they
do result from the emergence of the
state by Dynamics which are not obscure
now the new Palestinian State I believe
will be even worse certainly no better
in all of these respects I suspect it
will be a kind of a mirror image a
mirror image diminished in scale of the
Jewish state with a built-in
hopelessness and frustration and
bitterness and
failure in this way history I think will
realize the worst fears of the early
Zionist leaders people like Arthur rupin
who was in charge of colonization in the
1920s and who exactly 50 years
ago warned that a Jewish state of a
million or even a few million after 50
years will be nothing but a new
Montenegro or a new Lithuania herz's
concept of a Jewish state was possible
only because he ignored the presence of
the Arabs Zionism he urged must discard
Herzel diplomatic and imperialist
approach and he was not alone in this
view barl Kat Nelson another outstanding
Zionist leader in 1931 addressing a
mapai conference said I do not wish to
see the realization of Zionism in the
form of a new Polish state with Arabs in
the positions of the Jew in the position
of the Jews and Jews in the position of
the poles the ruling people for me this
would be the complete perversion of the
Zionist ideal Our Generation has been
witness to the fact that Nations aspire
iring to Freedom who threw off the Yoke
of subjugation rushed to place this yoke
on the shoulder of others over the
generations in which we were persecuted
and exiled and slaughtered we learned
not only the pain of Exile and
subjugation but also contempt for
tyranny was that only a case of sour
grapes are we now nurturing the dream of
slaves who wish to Reign I think it's
not too late for the answer to that
question to become no and I believe that
after the experience of living in their
new monegros and Lithuania Jews and
Arabs may turn to a better way a way
which has always been a
possibility this better way will be
based on the principle that neither
Nation will dominate the other each
people will have the right to
participate in self-governing
institutions any
individual self-governing National
institutions any individual will be free
to live where he wants to be free from
religious control if he wishes in my
opinion
this Society in the former Palestine
should be based on the principle that
all Palestinians who were driven from
their homes or who fled have the right
to return as do Jews who wish to find
their place in this National Homeland in
this Society there should be no
oppressive or discriminatory legislation
or any such administrative practice as
exists in the Jewish State and as will
certainly exist in the Palestinian State
as well it will not be a Jewish state it
will not be an Arab state but rather
multinational Democratic
Society now many schemes can be imagined
that would realize such principles as
these in a concrete way let me just cite
one which is by no means the only
one the regime must at all times assure
both the Jews and the Arabs the
possibility of unhampered development
and full National Independence so as to
rule out any Domination by Arabs of Jews
or by Jews of Arabs the regime must
Foster the approachment Accord and
cooperation of the Jewish people and the
Arabs in Palestine Palestine will be a
federal state comprising an alliance of
cantons autonomous districts some with
Jews in the majority some with Arabs
there will be National autonomy of each
people with exclusive Authority in the
matters of Education culture and
language matters of religion will be
under the control of autonomous
religious congregations organized as
free statutory bodies the highest body
of the state will be the Federal Council
consisting of two houses one
representing nationalities in which Jews
and Arabs will have equal representation
one in which the representation in which
representatives of the cantons will
participate in accordance in proportion
to their respective populations any
federal law and any change in the
Federal Constitution can be enacted with
only the agreement of both houses this I
think is a feasible way of realizing
these general principles incidentally
again this is not my view my idea rather
I was quoting from benan David benan in
a proposal that he made in
1930 uh and these were views that he
continued to repeat through the 1930s
pointing out in the 17th Zionist
Congress of
1931 that we declare before World
opinion before the workers movement and
before the Arab world that we shall not
agree either now or in the future to the
rule of One National Group over the
other nor do we accept the idea of a
Jewish state which would eventually mean
Jewish domination of Arabs and Palestine
and again in
1937 if pal vorian still if Palestine
were uninhabited we might have asked for
a Jewish State before then it would not
harm anyone else but there are other
residents in Palestine and just as we do
not wish to be at the mercy of others
they too have the right not to be at the
mercy of the
Jews now there are many who believe that
proposals such as these were put forth
hypocritically as a kind of a tactic I
don't agree what I've been quoting are
internal documents rather substantive
and concrete ones I think that they
reflected a commitment to Justice and an
understanding on the part of committed
socialists as to what a new Lithuania or
a new Montenegro would
become there are many reasons why such
plans failed but it is not necessary to
relive that history it seems to me that
at this moment it is critically
important for such alternatives to be
considered and debated and furthermore
to be imped by Jews and by Arabs who
will be repelled by the Imperial
settlement and who will seek a more
decent life for Jews I think this means
returning to the concept of Zionism
expressed by Old Settlers like Yak
Epstein a concept that has long been
forgotten for many years though it was
alive in the 1930s as it should have
been a concept of Zionism is based on
Justice and law on absolute equality and
human
Brotherhood
[Applause]
and now Alan dtz professor of law at
Harvard will also speak to the question
of what would you consider to be a just
and Lasting lasting solution in the
Middle East thank you I too want to
disclaim speaking on behalf of any
organization I'm uh not uh properly
labeled uh in the program as
representing a Zionist point of view uh
zionists and Israelis uh frequently
agree agree with me and frequently
disagree with me an article that I wrote
uh some years ago was quite critical of
uh some aspects of Israeli life and I
certainly don't want to be understood as
speaking on behalf of any group or any
organization I'm speaking for myself and
from deeply felt individual values uh
discussing the Middle East with Noom
chsky and before an organization
consisting primarily of people from the
peace Community is an opport Unity I
frankly long look forward to I've been
deeply involved in the peace community
and in the peace movement since its
Inception uh indeed I've probably
represented some of you or some
organizations that you belong to and
certainly some of your friends or people
with whom you identify uh I think I
share many of the same values that most
of you find important I generally view
the world in much the same way you view
it and I identify with most of the same
National and world leaders with whom you
identify for several years now I've been
agonizing with myself over the question
why then does so many of you come out so
differently than I do on the issues
surrounding the Arab Israeli dispute why
do so many people with whom I agree on
so many issues look upon the Israeli
cause with so much disdain and upon the
Arab cause particularly but not
exclusively the Palestinian cause with
so much approval to be sure many of you
would deny and properly so that
characterization you would say as the
American friend service committee
reports says that both sides are equally
right or as others have put it both
sides are equally wrong when I hear that
kind of argument I'm reminded of the old
story of the rabbi who uh heard the case
before him of a husband and wife in a
matrimonial situation and first he heard
the wife's version and said to the wife
you know you're right and then the
husband came in and told his version
which was completely inconsistent and
the rabbi said you know you're right and
the rabbi student who heard both these
said Rabbi that's absolutely
contradictory he can't be right and she
can't be right to which the rabbi said
you know you're
right it's a great virtue to see both
sides of an issue If there really are
comparable Rights and Wrongs on both
sides but in my view it's an equally
great Vice to see two comparable sides
to an issue when they are truly not
comparable as I have said I've been much
agonized by the fact that so many of you
with whom I agree on so much view the
issue so differently from the way I do I
hope that some of you too who support
the Arab cause have also been agonizing
since so many of those with whom you
agree on most other issues so many of
those with whom you have worked marched
struck been jailed feel so differently
from the way you do on that important
issue as judge learn at Han once said
the spirit of Liberty is the spirit
which is not too sure that it is right
and he was fond of quoting cromwell's
statement I beseech ye in the bowels of
Christ think that ye may be mistaken
that I submit as a healthy attitude with
which all of us might consider this
issue with this brief introduction of
mine let me try to identify some of the
values which I think we share a deep and
abiding commitment let's then ask
ourselves whether those values push so
inexorably toward the Arab side or
whether they even permit a moral person
to conclude as so many in the peace
movement have that there are comparable
equities and inequities on both sides am
I not correct in identifying the
following values as among those which we
all cherish most first of course is a
preference some of us would use a
stronger word for peace over War closely
related to that as a strong preference
for the values of life and Liberty over
those of land and property we all prefer
societies where political and civil
liberties are respected to those where
repression and tyranny exist certainly
those are the values from which
Professor Chomsky spoke tonight and most
of us I think have a strong affinity for
some kind of Socialism or at least for
an equal distribution or a more
equitable distribution of income we
support the goals of the women's
movement and we oppose Societies in
which the rights of women are not
recognized we oppose colonialism and the
denial of self-determination or
Community Control many of us will and
this perhaps is a value we do not all
share tend to identify with the underdog
with those who are being ganged up on
rather with than with those who seem to
have the support of the gang now I'm
sure there are other values as well that
we share but I think I'm correct in
concluding that most of us would put
those values at or near the top of any
list let's turn then to our preference
for peace over War and the related
preference for the values of life and
Liberty over those of land and property
and see on which side of the scale those
preferences justly belong to analyze
that issue it is I think best to
distinguish between the Middle East
situation as it existed before the 1967
war and the situation as it existed
prior to that War beginning with the
pre-1967 and focusing primarily on the
1947 49 period to which Professor chsky
alluded it's difficult for me to find
any justification for the massive
Egyptian Syrian and Jordanian attack on
